p: Beyond direct temperature effects, temperature can influence arboviruses indirectly through interactions with other variables. Drought has been found to be important in the amplification of Flaviviruses, with a strong association between drought and drier conditions and WNV [ 150, 180, 227, 228, 229, 230, 231] and SLEV [ 174, 201, 232, 233]. Increased snow depth was predictive of increased SINV in Finland [ 172], suggesting an indirect role of temperature on this virus. SLEV was found to increase indirectly with low temperatures [ 234]: winter freezes in Florida were associated with increased avian breeding success that resulted in a larger number of susceptible hosts [ 235].
